title: Large Reasoning Models (LRM) Efficiency Hierarchy
subtitle: Interactive Learning Experience for Efficient Reasoning Methods
description: Explore the comprehensive taxonomy of efficient reasoning methods in Large Reasoning Models through interactive diagrams and coding exercises
svgDiagram:
<svg viewBox="0 0 1400 1200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <!-- Define styles -->
  <defs>
    <style>
      .title-box { fill: #D8D8F6; stroke: #9999CC; stroke-width: 1; }
      .main-box { fill: #C8C8E8; stroke: #8888BB; stroke-width: 1; }
      .inference-box { fill: #FFE4B5; stroke: #DAA520; stroke-width: 1; cursor: pointer; }
      .inference-box:hover { fill: #FFD8A0; }
      .sft-box { fill: #E0D5F7; stroke: #8B7AA8; stroke-width: 1; cursor: pointer; }
      .sft-box:hover { fill: #D5C8F0; }
      .rl-box { fill: #FFE4E1; stroke: #CD5C5C; stroke-width: 1; cursor: pointer; }
      .rl-box:hover { fill: #FFD8D4; }
      .pretrain-box { fill: #B0E0E6; stroke: #4682B4; stroke-width: 1; cursor: pointer; }
      .pretrain-box:hover { fill: #A0D4DB; }
      .subquad-box { fill: #D4F1D4; stroke: #228B22; stroke-width: 1; cursor: pointer; }
      .subquad-box:hover { fill: #C8E8C8; }
      .future-box { fill: #FFDAB9; stroke: #CD853F; stroke-width: 1; cursor: pointer; }
      .future-box:hover { fill: #FFCEAD; }
      .text-main { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; fill: #333; font-weight: 500; }
      .text { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 9px; fill: #333; }
      .text-small { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 8px; fill: #333; }
      .connector { stroke: #666; stroke-width: 1; fill: none; }
    </style>
  </defs>

  <!-- Title -->
  <rect x="20" y="20" width="220" height="1160" class="title-box" rx="10"/>
  <text x="130" y="600" text-anchor="middle" class="text-main" transform="rotate(-90 130 600)">Hierarchy of Efficient Reasoning Methods in Large Reasoning Models (LRMs)</text>

  <!-- I. Efficient Reasoning during Inference -->
  <rect x="270" y="50" width="180" height="30" class="main-box" rx="5"/>
  <text x="360" y="69" text-anchor="middle" class="text-main">I. Efficient Reasoning during Inference</text>
  <line x1="240" y1="65" x2="270" y2="65" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 1. Length Budgeting -->
  <rect x="480" y="30" width="100" height="25" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="47" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Length Budgeting</text>
  <line x1="450" y1="65" x2="470" y2="65" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="65" x2="470" y2="42" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="42" x2="480" y2="42" class="connector"/>
  
  <g class="component" data-component="length-budgeting-papers">
    <rect x="600" y="10" width="320" height="90" class="inference-box" rx="3"/>
    <text x="610" y="25" class="text">TALE (Han et al., 2024)</text>
    <text x="610" y="38" class="text">Sketch-of-Thought (Aytes et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="610" y="51" class="text">Planning Tokens (Wang et al., 2023b)</text>
    <text x="610" y="64" class="text">Chain of Draft (Xu et al., 2025a)</text>
    <text x="610" y="77" class="text">S1 (Muennighoff et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="610" y="90" class="text">SafeChain (Jiang et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="760" y="25" class="text">DSC (Wang et al., 2024b)</text>
    <text x="760" y="38" class="text">Dynasor (Fu et al., 2024b)</text>
    <text x="760" y="51" class="text">TSP (Wang et al., 2025e)</text>
  </g>
  <line x1="580" y1="42" x2="600" y2="42" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 2. System Switch -->
  <rect x="480" y="110" width="100" height="35" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="123" text-anchor="middle" class="text">System Switch</text>
  <text x="530" y="135" text-anchor="middle" class="text-small">(System 1 â†” System 2)</text>
  <line x1="470" y1="65" x2="470" y2="127" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="127" x2="480" y2="127" class="connector"/>
  
  <g class="component" data-component="system-switch-papers">
    <rect x="600" y="110" width="320" height="50" class="inference-box" rx="3"/>
    <text x="610" y="125" class="text">Dualformer (Su et al., 2024a)</text>
    <text x="610" y="138" class="text">System 1.x (Saha et al., 2024)</text>
    <text x="610" y="151" class="text">FaST (Sun et al., 2025a)</text>
    <text x="760" y="125" class="text">HaluSearch (Cheng et al., 2025a)</text>
    <text x="760" y="138" class="text">Dyna-Think (Pan et al., 2024)</text>
  </g>
  <line x1="580" y1="127" x2="600" y2="127" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 3. Model Switch -->
  <rect x="480" y="170" width="100" height="25" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="187" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Model Switch</text>
  <line x1="470" y1="65" x2="470" y2="182" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="182" x2="480" y2="182" class="connector"/>
  
  <g class="component" data-component="model-switch-papers">
    <rect x="600" y="170" width="320" height="65" class="inference-box" rx="3"/>
    <text x="610" y="185" class="text">BiLD (Kim et al., 2023)</text>
    <text x="610" y="198" class="text">EAGLE / EAGLE-2 (Li et al., 2024e, 2024d)</text>
    <text x="610" y="211" class="text">MEDUSA (Cai et al., 2024)</text>
    <text x="610" y="224" class="text">LayerSkip (Elhoushi et al., 2024)</text>
    <text x="760" y="185" class="text">Zooter (Lu et al., 2023)</text>
    <text x="760" y="198" class="text">RouteLLM (Ong et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="760" y="211" class="text">MixLLM (Wang et al., 2025b)</text>
  </g>
  <line x1="580" y1="182" x2="600" y2="182" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 4. Parallel Search -->
  <rect x="480" y="245" width="100" height="25" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="262" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Parallel Search</text>
  <line x1="470" y1="65" x2="470" y2="257" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="257" x2="480" y2="257" class="connector"/>
  
  <g class="component" data-component="parallel-search-papers">
    <rect x="600" y="245" width="320" height="65" class="inference-box" rx="3"/>
    <text x="610" y="260" class="text">SBoN (Sun et al., 2024a)</text>
    <text x="610" y="273" class="text">TreeBoN (Qiu et al., 2024)</text>
    <text x="610" y="286" class="text">STBoN (Wang et al., 2025d)</text>
    <text x="610" y="299" class="text">SelfCalibration (Huang et al., 2025a)</text>
    <text x="760" y="260" class="text">MetaReasoner (Sui et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="760" y="273" class="text">TPO (Li et al., 2025d)</text>
  </g>
  <line x1="580" y1="257" x2="600" y2="257" class="connector"/>

  <!-- II. Efficient Reasoning with SFT -->
  <rect x="270" y="330" width="180" height="30" class="main-box" rx="5"/>
  <text x="360" y="349" text-anchor="middle" class="text-main">II. Efficient Reasoning with SFT</text>
  <line x1="240" y1="345" x2="270" y2="345" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 1. Reasoning Chain Compression -->
  <rect x="480" y="320" width="100" height="35" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="333" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Reasoning Chain</text>
  <text x="530" y="345" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Compression</text>
  <line x1="450" y1="345" x2="470" y2="345" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="345" x2="470" y2="337" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="337" x2="480" y2="337" class="connector"/>
  
  <g class="component" data-component="chain-compression-papers">
    <rect x="600" y="320" width="320" height="65" class="sft-box" rx="3"/>
    <text x="610" y="335" class="text">TokenSkip (Xia et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="610" y="348" class="text">SPIRIT-FT (Cui et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="610" y="361" class="text">Skip Steps (Liu et al., 2024c)</text>
    <text x="610" y="374" class="text">Distill System 2 (Yu et al., 2024a)</text>
    <text x="760" y="335" class="text">C3ot (Kang et al., 2024)</text>
    <text x="760" y="348" class="text">Self-Training (Munkhbat et al., 2025)</text>
  </g>
  <line x1="580" y1="337" x2="600" y2="337" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 2. Latent-Space SFT -->
  <rect x="480" y="395" width="100" height="25" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="412" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Latent-Space SFT</text>
  <line x1="470" y1="345" x2="470" y2="407" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="407" x2="480" y2="407" class="connector"/>
  
  <g class="component" data-component="latent-sft-papers">
    <rect x="600" y="395" width="320" height="90" class="sft-box" rx="3"/>
    <text x="610" y="410" class="text">Coconut (Hao et al., 2024)</text>
    <text x="610" y="423" class="text">CCoT (Cheng and Van Durme, 2024)</text>
    <text x="610" y="436" class="text">CODI (Shen et al., 2025c)</text>
    <text x="610" y="449" class="text">Token Assorted (Su et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="610" y="462" class="text">SoftCoT (Xu et al., 2025b)</text>
    <text x="610" y="475" class="text">Heima (Shen et al., 2025a)</text>
    <text x="760" y="410" class="text">Implicit CoT (Deng et al., 2024)</text>
    <text x="760" y="423" class="text">LightThinker (Zhang et al., 2025a)</text>
  </g>
  <line x1="580" y1="407" x2="600" y2="407" class="connector"/>

  <!-- III. Efficient Reasoning with RL -->
  <rect x="270" y="505" width="180" height="30" class="main-box" rx="5"/>
  <text x="360" y="524" text-anchor="middle" class="text-main">III. Efficient Reasoning with RL</text>
  <line x1="240" y1="520" x2="270" y2="520" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 1. With Length Reward -->
  <rect x="480" y="495" width="100" height="25" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="512" text-anchor="middle" class="text">With Length Reward</text>
  <line x1="450" y1="520" x2="470" y2="520" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="520" x2="470" y2="507" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="507" x2="480" y2="507" class="connector"/>
  
  <g class="component" data-component="rl-length-papers">
    <rect x="600" y="495" width="320" height="65" class="rl-box" rx="3"/>
    <text x="610" y="510" class="text">O1-Pruner (Luo et al., 2025a)</text>
    <text x="610" y="523" class="text">Training (Arora and Zanette, 2025)</text>
    <text x="610" y="536" class="text">L1 (Aggarwal and Welleck, 2025)</text>
    <text x="610" y="549" class="text">Kimi-1.5 (Team et al., 2025)</text>
    <text x="760" y="510" class="text">DAST (Shen et al., 2025b)</text>
    <text x="760" y="523" class="text">Demystifying (Yeo et al., 2025)</text>
  </g>
  <line x1="580" y1="507" x2="600" y2="507" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 2. Without Length Reward -->
  <rect x="480" y="570" width="100" height="35" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="583" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Without Length</text>
  <text x="530" y="595" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Reward</text>
  <line x1="470" y1="520" x2="470" y2="587" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="587" x2="480" y2="587" class="connector"/>
  
  <g class="component" data-component="rl-without-papers">
    <rect x="600" y="570" width="320" height="50" class="rl-box" rx="3"/>
    <text x="610" y="585" class="text">Meta-RL (MRT) (Qu et al., 2025b)</text>
    <text x="610" y="598" class="text">IBPO (Yu et al., 2025b)</text>
    <text x="610" y="611" class="text">Overthink (Chen et al., 2025c)</text>
    <text x="760" y="585" class="text">Dr.GRPO (Liu et al., 2025c)</text>
  </g>
  <line x1="580" y1="587" x2="600" y2="587" class="connector"/>

  <!-- IV. Efficient Reasoning during Pretraining -->
  <rect x="270" y="640" width="180" height="30" class="main-box" rx="5"/>
  <text x="360" y="659" text-anchor="middle" class="text-main">IV. Efficient Reasoning during Pretraining</text>
  <line x1="240" y1="655" x2="270" y2="655" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 1. Latent-space Pretraining -->
  <rect x="480" y="630" width="100" height="35" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="643" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Latent-space</text>
  <text x="530" y="655" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Pretraining</text>
  <line x1="450" y1="655" x2="470" y2="655" class="connector"/>

  <line x1="580" y1="647" x2="600" y2="647" class="connector"/>

  <line x1="470" y1="655" x2="470" y2="707" class="connector"/>
  <line x1="470" y1="707" x2="480" y2="707" class="connector"/>

  <line x1="580" y1="707" x2="600" y2="707" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 3. Linearization -->
  <rect x="480" y="790" width="100" height="25" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="530" y="807" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Linearization</text>

  <!-- V. Efficient Reasoning with Subquadratic Attention -->
  <rect x="270" y="850" width="180" height="50" class="main-box" rx="5"/>
  <text x="360" y="869" text-anchor="middle" class="text-main">V. Efficient Reasoning with</text>

  <line x1="240" y1="875" x2="270" y2="875" class="connector"/>

  <!-- VI. Future Directions -->
  <rect x="270" y="920" width="180" height="30" class="main-box" rx="5"/>
  <text x="360" y="939" text-anchor="middle" class="text-main">VI. Future Directions</text>
  <line x1="240" y1="935" x2="270" y2="935" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 1. Efficient Multimodality -->
  <rect x="480" y="900" width="120" height="35" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="540" y="913" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Efficient Multimodality</text>

  </g>
  <line x1="600" y1="917" x2="620" y2="917" class="connector"/>
  
  <!-- 2. Efficient Test-time Scaling -->
  <rect x="480" y="950" width="120" height="35" class="main-box" rx="3"/>
  <text x="540" y="963" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Efficient Test-time</text>
  <text x="540" y="975" text-anchor="middle" class="text">Scaling & Infinity Thinking</text>

  <!-- 3. Efficient and Trustworthy -->

length-budgeting.title: Length Budgeting
length-budgeting.explanation: Methods that control the computational budget by limiting the length of reasoning chains. These approaches dynamically adjust how many reasoning steps to perform based on problem difficulty, avoiding overthinking on simple problems while allocating more compute to complex ones.

system-switch.title: System Switch (System 1 â†” System 2)
system-switch.explanation: Techniques that switch between fast, intuitive reasoning (System 1) and slow, deliberative reasoning (System 2). These methods intelligently route queries to appropriate reasoning modes, using lightweight models for simple tasks and invoking heavy reasoning only when necessary.

model-switch.title: Model Switch
model-switch.explanation: Approaches that dynamically select or switch between different models during inference. This includes using smaller models for initial processing and larger models for refinement, or routing to specialized models based on task requirements.

parallel-search.title: Parallel Search
parallel-search.explanation: Methods that explore multiple reasoning paths simultaneously rather than sequentially. These include best-of-N sampling, tree-based search, and self-calibration techniques that generate and evaluate multiple candidate solutions in parallel.

chain-compression.title: Reasoning Chain Compression
chain-compression.explanation: Supervised fine-tuning methods that learn to compress verbose reasoning chains into more efficient representations. These approaches train models to skip redundant steps, use shortcuts, or internalize reasoning patterns to reduce inference-time computation.

latent-sft.title: Latent-Space SFT
latent-sft.explanation: Fine-tuning approaches that operate in latent space rather than token space. These methods learn compressed representations of reasoning processes, allowing models to perform implicit reasoning without generating explicit chain-of-thought tokens.

rl-length.title: RL with Length Reward
rl-length.explanation: Reinforcement learning methods that explicitly reward shorter reasoning chains. These approaches balance accuracy with efficiency by incorporating length penalties into the reward function, encouraging models to find concise solutions.

rl-without-length.title: RL without Length Reward
rl-without-length.explanation: RL methods focused purely on improving reasoning quality without explicit length constraints. These approaches may still achieve efficiency gains through emergent optimization of reasoning strategies, even without direct length incentives.

latent-pretrain.title: Latent-space Pretraining
latent-pretrain.explanation: Pretraining methods that learn reasoning in compressed latent representations from the start. Rather than learning token-by-token generation, these approaches train models to manipulate abstract reasoning states efficiently.

subquad-attention.title: Subquadratic Attention
subquad-attention.explanation: Architectural innovations that reduce the quadratic complexity of attention mechanisms. These include linear attention variants, state-space models, and hybrid architectures that maintain reasoning capabilities while dramatically reducing computational costs.

linearization.title: Linearization
linearization.explanation: Methods that convert transformer architectures to linear-complexity alternatives. These approaches use techniques like diagonal approximations or recurrent formulations to achieve O(n) complexity while preserving reasoning abilities.

subquad-reasoning.title: Efficient Reasoning with Subquadratic Attention
subquad-reasoning.explanation: Specialized reasoning methods designed for subquadratic architectures. These techniques adapt chain-of-thought and other reasoning strategies to work efficiently with linear attention mechanisms and state-space models.

multimodal.title: Efficient Multimodality and Video Reasoning
multimodal.explanation: Future direction focusing on extending efficient reasoning to multimodal inputs. This includes handling video sequences, cross-modal reasoning, and efficient processing of high-dimensional sensory data alongside text.

test-time-scaling.title: Efficient Test-time Scaling
test-time-scaling.explanation: Methods for dynamically scaling computation at inference time. These include adaptive computation techniques and 'infinity thinking' approaches that can allocate arbitrary amounts of compute based on problem difficulty and available resources.

trustworthy.title: Efficient and Trustworthy Reasoning
trustworthy.explanation: Approaches that maintain reasoning transparency and reliability while improving efficiency. This includes methods for verifiable reasoning chains, uncertainty quantification, and maintaining interpretability in compressed reasoning.

applications.title: Efficient Reasoning Applications
applications.explanation: Domain-specific applications of efficient reasoning. This includes retrieval-augmented reasoning, agent-based systems, and specialized applications where reasoning efficiency is critical for real-world deployment.

evaluation.title: Evaluation and Benchmark
evaluation.explanation: Benchmarks and evaluation frameworks specifically designed for efficient reasoning. These measure not just accuracy but also computational efficiency, overthinking detection, and the quality-efficiency tradeoff.

length-budgeting-papers.title: Length Budgeting Papers
length-budgeting-papers.explanation: Collection of papers implementing various approaches to control reasoning length through budget allocation strategies.

system-switch-papers.title: System Switch Papers
system-switch-papers.explanation: Papers exploring dynamic switching between fast and slow reasoning systems based on task complexity.

model-switch-papers.title: Model Switch Papers
model-switch-papers.explanation: Research on dynamically selecting or switching between different model sizes and architectures during inference.

parallel-search-papers.title: Parallel Search Papers
parallel-search-papers.explanation: Studies on exploring multiple reasoning paths simultaneously for improved efficiency and accuracy.

chain-compression-papers.title: Chain Compression Papers
chain-compression-papers.explanation: Work on compressing verbose reasoning chains through supervised fine-tuning approaches.

latent-sft-papers.title: Latent-Space SFT Papers
latent-sft-papers.explanation: Research on fine-tuning models to reason in compressed latent representations rather than explicit tokens.

rl-length-papers.title: RL with Length Reward Papers
rl-length-papers.explanation: Studies using reinforcement learning with explicit length penalties to optimize reasoning efficiency.

rl-without-papers.title: RL without Length Reward Papers
rl-without-papers.explanation: RL approaches focusing on reasoning quality without explicit length constraints.

latent-pretrain-papers.title: Latent-space Pretraining Papers
latent-pretrain-papers.explanation: Work on pretraining models to manipulate abstract reasoning states from the start.

subquad-attention-papers.title: Subquadratic Attention Papers
subquad-attention-papers.explanation: Research on reducing attention complexity while maintaining reasoning capabilities.

linearization-papers.title: Linearization Papers
linearization-papers.explanation: Studies on converting transformers to linear-complexity architectures.

subquad-reasoning-papers.title: Efficient Reasoning with Subquadratic Attention Papers
subquad-reasoning-papers.explanation: Work on adapting reasoning strategies for subquadratic architectures.

multimodal-papers.title: Multimodal Efficiency Papers
multimodal-papers.explanation: Research on extending efficient reasoning to multimodal and video inputs.

test-time-papers.title: Test-time Scaling Papers
test-time-papers.explanation: Studies on dynamic computation allocation during inference.

trustworthy-papers.title: Trustworthy Reasoning Papers
trustworthy-papers.explanation: Work on maintaining transparency and reliability in efficient reasoning.

applications-papers.title: Application Papers
applications-papers.explanation: Domain-specific applications of efficient reasoning techniques.

evaluation-papers.title: Evaluation Papers
evaluation-papers.explanation: Benchmarks and metrics for assessing reasoning efficiency.

concepts.title: TALE Budget Estimation
concepts.question: How does TALE estimate the optimal token budget for model generation?
concepts.answer: TALE uses zero-shot prompting to estimate an optimal token budget which constrains model generation

concepts.title: Sketch-of-Thought Paradigms
concepts.question: What are the three adaptive paradigms used by Sketch-of-Thought to reduce verbosity in intermediate reasoning steps?
concepts.answer: Conceptual Chaining, Chunked Symbolism, and Expert Lexicon

concepts.title: Planning Tokens Hierarchy
concepts.question: How do planning tokens enhance language model reasoning according to Wang et al. (2023b)?
concepts.answer: By incorporating planning tokens at the start of each reasoning step in a hierarchical approach

concepts.title: Chain-of-Draft Efficiency
concepts.question: What is the key difference between Chain-of-Draft and traditional CoT?
concepts.answer: Chain-of-Draft encourages models to generate concise, minimal intermediate reasoning steps rather than token-heavy explanations

concepts.title: S1 Budget Forcing
concepts.question: How does S1 directly control thinking length?
concepts.answer: Uses a budget-forcing strategy by appending an end-of-thinking token delimiter to force the thinking process to end

concepts.title: SafeChain Decoding
concepts.question: What are the two decoding strategies proposed by SafeChain to control thinking?
concepts.answer: ZeroThink (forces model to start response without any thought) and LessThink (forces a short thought process)

concepts.title: DSC Resource Allocation
concepts.question: How does Difficulty-Adaptive Self-Consistency (DSC) allocate inference resources?
concepts.answer: Evaluates query difficulty using the LLM itself to dynamically allocate inference resources

concepts.title: Dynasor Compute Allocation
concepts.question: What basis does Dynasor use to allocate compute during multi-path reasoning?
concepts.answer: Allocates compute based on model certainty, assigning more resources to hard queries

concepts.title: Thought Switching Penalty
concepts.question: What does TSP discourage to improve reasoning efficiency?
concepts.answer: Discourages premature transitions between thoughts which may cause superficial but lengthy reasoning traces

concepts.title: Dualformer Integration
concepts.question: How does Dualformer integrate the dual process through its training strategy?
concepts.answer: Uses a randomized reasoning trace training strategy that randomly drops certain parts of the reasoning traces

concepts.title: System 1.x Controller
concepts.question: What role does the controller play in System 1.x when handling maze tasks?
concepts.answer: Assesses maze difficulty to allow the model to alternate among different systems based on user-defined parameters for smoother cognitive resource allocation

concepts.title: FaST Visual Reasoning
concepts.question: What factors does FaST's switching adapter use to transition between Systems 1 and 2 for visual reasoning?
concepts.answer: Task complexity factors like visual uncertainty and invisibility

concepts.title: HaluSearch Learning
concepts.question: How does HaluSearch learn to switch between System 1 and System 2?
concepts.answer: Leverages model performance on specific instances to construct supervised labels for both instance-level and step-level switching under MCTS

concepts.title: Dyna-Think Autonomy
concepts.question: What makes Dyna-Think's dynamic thinking mechanism 'training-free'?
concepts.answer: The model autonomously determines 'Slow' reasoning based on generation consistency and complexity of thought processes

concepts.title: BiLD Dual Model
concepts.question: How does BiLD balance speed and quality through its policies?
concepts.answer: Uses a small, fast model for initial predictions and a larger, more accurate model for corrections through fallback and rollback policies

concepts.title: EAGLE Feature-Level
concepts.question: What key transition does EAGLE make to enhance inference?
concepts.answer: Transitions speculative sampling from the token level to the feature level

concepts.title: EAGLE-2 Dynamic Trees
concepts.question: What innovation does EAGLE-2 introduce for speculative decoding?
concepts.answer: Context-aware dynamic draft trees that adjust token acceptance rates based on confidence scores

concepts.title: MEDUSA Multi-Token
concepts.question: How does MEDUSA reduce sequential decoding steps?
concepts.answer: Incorporates additional decoding heads that predict multiple tokens simultaneously with a tree-based attention mechanism to concurrently generate and verify candidate continuations

concepts.title: LayerSkip Early Exit
concepts.question: What two techniques does LayerSkip combine to speed up inference?
concepts.answer: Layer dropout combined with early exit loss, allowing predictions at shallower layers with self-speculative decoding for verification

concepts.title: Zooter Routing
concepts.question: How does Zooter's reward-guided routing method determine which LLM to use?
concepts.answer: Leverages distilled rewards from training queries to train a specialized routing function that directs each query to the LLM with the most pertinent expertise

concepts.title: RouteLLM Balance
concepts.question: What balance does RouteLLM strike through its dynamic routing?
concepts.answer: Dynamically routes queries between robust and weaker language models to achieve optimal balance between performance and cost effectiveness

concepts.title: MixLLM Decision Making
concepts.question: How does MixLLM enhance its selection of optimal LLM candidates?
concepts.answer: Enhances query embeddings using tag knowledge, employs lightweight predictors to assess quality and cost per model, and uses a meta decision maker

concepts.title: SBoN Early Halting
concepts.question: How does SBoN achieve comparable performance while reducing computational demands?
concepts.answer: Evaluates partial responses and halts those that are unlikely to yield high-quality completions

concepts.title: TreeBoN Hierarchical
concepts.question: What combination does TreeBoN use and how does it manage candidates?
concepts.answer: Combines speculative tree-search with Best-of-N sampling, generating candidates in hierarchical tree structure and pruning low-quality ones early using weighted implicit reward

concepts.title: STBoN Truncation
concepts.question: How does STBoN identify when to truncate suboptimal candidates?
concepts.answer: Identifies the earliest estimation time when samples become distinct and employs a buffer window along with hidden state consistency

concepts.title: Self-Calibration Distillation
concepts.question: What does Self-Calibration distill into the model and what benefit does this provide?
concepts.answer: Distills self-consistency-derived confidence into the model, enabling strategies like early stopping and eliminating the need for external reward models

concepts.title: MetaReasoner Formulation
concepts.question: What formulation does MetaReasoner use for its strategies like restarting or refining?
concepts.answer: Uses a contextual multi-armed bandit formulation

concepts.title: TPO Recursive Approach
concepts.question: What does TPO's recursive approach achieve compared to training-aware methods?
concepts.answer: Revises parallel samples to align model performance at test time, achieving comparable results to training-aware methods

concepts.title: TokenSkip Analysis
concepts.question: How does TokenSkip achieve controllable compression of CoT sequences?
concepts.answer: Analyzes token importance in CoT outputs and selectively omits less important tokens

concepts.title: SPIRIT-FT Metric
concepts.question: What metric does SPIRIT-FT use to identify critical reasoning steps?
concepts.answer: Uses perplexity as a metric - a step is deemed critical if its removal significantly increases perplexity

concepts.title: LM-Skip Environment
concepts.question: How does LM-Skip induce step-skipping behavior?
concepts.answer: Designs a controlled training environment that instructs models to produce reasoning sequences under a step constraint

concepts.title: Distill System 2
concepts.question: When does Yu et al.'s approach fine-tune models to omit intermediate generation steps?
concepts.answer: For samples that are sufficiently confident

concepts.title: C3ot Compression
concepts.question: How does C3ot preserve key information and learn compression?
concepts.answer: Employs GPT-4 as a compressor to preserve key information, then fine-tunes to learn the relationship between long and short CoTs

concepts.title: Self-Training Distillation
concepts.question: What two techniques does Munkhbat et al.'s self-training use before applying SFT?
concepts.answer: Best-of-N sampling and few-shot conditioning to build concise reasoning paths

concepts.title: Coconut Continuous Thought
concepts.question: How does Coconut (Chain of Continuous Thought) replace traditional CoT?
concepts.answer: Uses the model's last hidden state as a continuous representation of reasoning, feeding it back into the model as input for subsequent reasoning steps

concepts.title: CCoT Compression
concepts.question: How does CCoT reduce computational cost and enhance throughput?
concepts.answer: Fine-tunes the model to produce compressed representations of reasoning chains instead of full-length sequences, approximating complete chains with fewer tokens

concepts.title: CODI Distillation
concepts.question: What does CODI align between teacher and student models?
concepts.answer: Aligns hidden activations of specific tokens between a teacher model using explicit CoT and a student model using implicit CoT

concepts.title: Token Assorted Mixing
concepts.question: How does Token Assorted abstract initial reasoning steps?
concepts.answer: Mixes latent discrete tokens from VQ-VAE with text tokens to abstract the initial reasoning steps while retaining essential information

concepts.title: SoftCoT Assistant
concepts.question: How does SoftCoT approach continuous-space reasoning differently?
concepts.answer: Utilizes an assistant model that generates 'soft thought tokens' for the LLM

concepts.title: LightThinker Compression
concepts.question: How does LightThinker enhance reasoning efficiency?
concepts.answer: Dynamically compresses intermediate steps into concise latent representations

concepts.title: Heima Architecture
concepts.question: How does Heima reduce verbosity in both text and multimodal tasks?
concepts.answer: The Heima Encoder compresses intermediate steps into a single token, and the Heima Decoder reconstructs the reasoning process from these tokens

concepts.title: Implicit CoT
concepts.question: What is the key characteristic of Implicit CoT by Deng et al.?
concepts.answer: Performs reasoning in latent space without generating explicit chain-of-thought tokens

concepts.title: O1-Pruner Method
concepts.question: How does O1-Pruner begin its efficient fine-tuning method?
concepts.answer: Begins by estimating the LLM's baseline performance through presampling from its reference model

concepts.title: Normalized Length Penalty
concepts.question: How does Arora and Zanette's length penalty ensure correct responses are preferred?
concepts.answer: Introduces a length penalty normalized in the per-prompt group, ensuring correct responses are always preferred over incorrect ones regardless of token count

concepts.title: LCPO Target Control
concepts.question: How does LCPO control length budget through prompts and rewards?
concepts.answer: Introduces target length instruction in the prompt ('Think for ngold tokens') and designs a target-aware length reward that penalizes length violation

concepts.title: Kimi 1.5 Observation
concepts.question: What phenomenon does Kimi 1.5 observe and how does it address it?
concepts.answer: Observes the overthinking phenomenon and introduces a length reward to restrain the rapid growth of token length

concepts.title: DAST Adaptive Thinking
concepts.question: How does DAST empower models to modulate CoT length?
concepts.answer: Introduces Difficulty-Adaptive Slow-Thinking that allows models to autonomously modulate CoT length based on problem complexity

concepts.title: Demystifying Paradox
concepts.question: What paradoxical finding did Yeo et al. reveal about extremely long CoT reasoning?
concepts.answer: Extremely long CoT reasoning approaching context limits paradoxically reduces accuracy; they proposed a cosine reward function for intuitive guidance

concepts.title: MRT Formulation
concepts.question: How does MRT (Meta-RL) structure its test-time optimization approach?
concepts.answer: Formulates test-time optimization as a meta-reinforcement learning problem, dividing generation into episodes with model estimating answers after each episode

concepts.title: IBPO Framing
concepts.question: How does IBPO approach budget awareness differently than direct length control?
concepts.answer: Frames budget awareness as utility maximization rather than directly controlling response length

concepts.title: Overthink Heuristics
concepts.question: What heuristics does Overthink employ for generating preference data?
concepts.answer: Uses First-Correct Solutions (FCS) and Greedy Diverse Solutions (GDS) to generate preference data for offline policy optimization using DPO, RPO, and SimPO

concepts.title: Dr.GRPO Approach
concepts.question: What is Dr.GRPO's focus in reasoning without length rewards?
concepts.answer: Focuses on improving reasoning quality through group relative policy optimization without explicit length constraints

concepts.title: BLT Processing
concepts.question: How does Byte Latent Transformer process input differently than traditional models?
concepts.answer: Processes raw bytes using dynamically sized patches rather than fixed tokens, reducing computational overhead and improving robustness

concepts.title: LCMs Semantic Level
concepts.question: What serves as the primary processing units in Large Concept Models?
concepts.answer: Abstract concepts that often correspond to complete sentences or speech utterances

concepts.title: CoCoMix Integration
concepts.question: What two types of predictions does CoCoMix integrate?
concepts.answer: Integrates discrete token prediction with continuous concept vectors derived from sparse autoencoders (SAEs)

concepts.title: LTMs Guidance
concepts.question: How do latent thought vectors (LTMs) influence token generation?
concepts.answer: Probabilistically guide token generation via cross-attention mechanisms

concepts.title: Lightning Attention
concepts.question: What does Lightning Attention optimize to expedite processing?
concepts.answer: Optimizes I/O operations to expedite processing

concepts.title: LASP-2 Refinement
concepts.question: How does LASP-2 refine the Lightning Attention approach?
concepts.answer: Further refines by reorganizing both computational and communication workflows

concepts.title: GLA Gating
concepts.question: What scheme does Gated Linear Attention use to enhance sequence modeling?
concepts.answer: Leverages a data-independent gating scheme to enhance sequence modeling ability and hardware efficiency

concepts.title: Gated DeltaNet Updates
concepts.question: What capability do TTT, Titans, and Gated-DeltaNet share?
concepts.answer: Propose update rules that allow models to adapt dynamically during inference

concepts.title: MoM Memory
concepts.question: How does MoM expand the RNN memory state?
concepts.answer: Uses 'sparse memory' with multiple memory units managed by a router module

concepts.title: Mamba-2 Integration
concepts.question: What does Mamba-2 integrate to enhance hardware efficiency?
concepts.answer: Integrates a linear attention-like mechanism

concepts.title: RWKV-7 Method
concepts.question: What category of methods does RWKV-7 belong to?
concepts.answer: Linear RNN-based methods that have demonstrated effectiveness

concepts.title: NSA Strategy
concepts.question: What hierarchical strategy does NSA adopt?
concepts.answer: Dynamic hierarchical sparse strategy combining coarse-grained token compression with fine-grained token selection

concepts.title: MoBA Routing
concepts.question: How does MoBA handle context and routing?
concepts.answer: Divides context into blocks and uses dynamic gating mechanism to route query tokens to the most relevant KV blocks

concepts.title: Liger Modification
concepts.question: How does Liger modify pre-trained LLMs without extra parameters?
concepts.answer: Modifies pre-trained LLMs into gated linear recurrent models by adapting key matrix weights

concepts.title: Llamba Distillation
concepts.question: What does Llamba achieve through MOHAWK with minimal training data?
concepts.answer: Distills Llama-3.x models into the Mamba architecture, achieving high inference throughput and efficiency

concepts.title: LoLCATs Enhancement
concepts.question: How does LoLCATs advance LLM linearization?
concepts.answer: Replaces softmax attention with trained linear approximations and enhances model quality using LoRA

subquad-reasoning-papers.title: Efficient Reasoning with Subquadratic Attention Papers

concepts.title: Think Slow Fast
concepts.question: What does TSF demonstrate about distilling Mamba models from Transformers?
concepts.answer: Demonstrates that distilling Mamba models from Transformers enables faster multi-path CoT generation under fixed compute budgets

concepts.title: CRQs Expressiveness
concepts.question: What does CRQs examine regarding different model architectures?
concepts.answer: Examines the expressiveness of Transformers, RNNs, and CoT-augmented models on Compositional Reasoning Questions

concepts.title: Cosmos-Reason1 Architecture
concepts.question: What hybrid architecture does Cosmos-Reason1 use for efficient Physical AI reasoning?
concepts.answer: Uses hybrid Mamba-MLP-Transformer backbone architecture

concepts.title: SCoT Decomposition
concepts.question: How does Self-structured Chain of Thought (SCoT) address multimodal reasoning issues?
concepts.answer: Decomposes reasoning tasks into atomic, semantically meaningful steps

concepts.title: AL-CoTD Adaptation
concepts.question: How does AL-CoTD refine the reasoning process?
concepts.answer: Dynamically adjusts the length of reasoning chains according to task complexity

concepts.title: Heima Multimodal
concepts.question: What capability does Heima provide for multimodal tasks?
concepts.answer: Leverages hidden latent representations to reduce verbosity in both text and multimodal tasks

concepts.title: Confidence-Based Methods
concepts.question: How can inefficient reasoning be mitigated according to Huang et al.?
concepts.answer: By developing confidence-based methods to address queries of varying difficulty

concepts.title: Adaptive Sampling
concepts.question: What type of strategies do Wan et al. and others propose for test-time scaling?
concepts.answer: Adaptive sampling strategies for dynamic computation allocation

concepts.title: Deliberative Alignment
concepts.question: What approach does deliberative alignment offer for LRM safety?
concepts.answer: Offers a distinct approach to enhance LRM safety through deliberative processes

concepts.title: X-Boundary
concepts.question: What is X-Boundary's contribution to LRM safety?
concepts.answer: Provides a distinct approach to enhance LRM safety alongside deliberative alignment

concepts.title: Chain-of-Retrieval
concepts.question: How do O1-like RAG models trained with Wang et al.'s method operate?
concepts.answer: Perform step-by-step retrieval and reasoning over relevant information before generating the final answer

concepts.title: Agent Overthinking
concepts.question: What correlation did Cuadron et al. find in magnetic tasks?
concepts.answer: Elevated overthinking scores correlate negatively with performance

concepts.title: Efficiency Metrics
concepts.question: What two perspectives do Chen et al.'s efficiency metrics address?
concepts.answer: Both outcome and process perspectives

concepts.title: DNA Bench
concepts.question: What vulnerability does DNA Bench expose in LRMs?
concepts.answer: LRMs' tendency for over-reasoning
